channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: 'He is the people's president!' Ivanka Trump introduces her father at RNC
item.description: Ivanka Trump introduced her father as 'the People's President' during her Thursday night speech at the Republican National Convention, delivering her remarks from the White House's South Lawn.

item.title: Liam Payne, 26, and Maya Henry, 20, are ENGAGED! Model is seen showing off dazzling £3million ring
item.description: The former One Direction heartthrob 26, popped the question with a dazzling diamond ring that set him back an eye-watering £3 million.

item.title: Trump ignores CDC guidelines for his convention speech
item.description: President Trump's speech to the Republican National Convention will feature 1,500 guests on the South Lawn with no social distancing, no mask mandate and only a few of them tested for COVID

item.title: Lawyers for Kyle Rittenhouse set up legal defense fund after teen is charged with homicide
item.description: Defense attorney Lin Wood said the Fight Back Foundation will be collecting donations for Kyle Rittenhouse's defense. The 17-year-old was formally charged with homicide on Thursday.

item.title: Carol Smillie reveals she'd happily revive role on Changing Rooms amid reports it's coming back
item.description: It has been claimed that TV bosses are eyeing Carole, 58, and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, 55, to bring their property sprucing magic back to homes on a tight budget once again.

item.title: I'm A Celebrity 2020 filming location is CONFIRMED as 200-year-old Gwrych Castle in Wales
item.description: The ITV show will be based at the historic site nestled in the Welsh countryside, after production was forced to be relocated from Australia due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Ant McPartlin and Declan Donnelly reveal they had showdown with Simon Cowell over quitting BGT
item.description: The pair admitted in their new book Once Upon A Tyne, they had crisis talks with Simon in Los Angeles in 2012 where they told him they were considering walking away from Britain's Got Talent.

item.title: 97% of head teachers say they are all set to welcome pupils back full-time when term begins
item.description: In a boost to the UK government, the National Association of Head Teachers union said 97 per cent of schools were ready to reopen on schedule.

item.title: EastEnders bosses reveal secrets to filming during COVID-19 crisis as soap returns to screens
item.description: EastEnders bosses offered fans their first glimpse of filming in the world of COVID-19, as the soap makes its long-awaited return to screens next month after three months off air.

item.title: Camilla Thurlow admits going Love Island was more scary than clearing land mines in new memoir
item.description: Camilla Thurlow who is best known for appearing on UK reality dating show Love Island in 2017, has penned a memoir reflecting on the ups and downs of her 20s.

item.title: Alexa gets a language lesson... from Susie Dent!
item.description: Amazon's Alexa smart speaker has been given some lessons in Geordie, Brummie and Glaswegian to help it with some of our quirkier dialects. Pictured: Susie Dent.

item.title: Model, 25, is slammed for posting a video of what she looks like without 'posing'
item.description: An Australian model has been criticised for sharing a video of her body 'posed' and 'unposed' - with very little difference - before saying she needed to research body positivity.

item.title: Deportation flight is cancelled after last-minute legal challenges
item.description: The plane was scheduled to leave the UK for Spain on Thursday morning, but had to be scrapped while the appeals are considered.

item.title: Diamond price falls mean engagement rings are cheaper thanks to Covid
item.description: The world's biggest diamond producers have slashed the cost of rough diamonds by up to 10 per cent after months of low demand due to coronavirus.

item.title: British-Israeli woman sues Easyjet for £15,000 after they make her move seats twice
item.description: Melanie Wolfson, 38, is claiming 66,438 shekels compensation from the low-cost airline in a lawsuit filed on her behalf by the Israel Religious Action Center (IRAC).

item.title: Jacob Blake's father says his paralyzed son is being kept in HANDCUFFS in hospital
item.description: Jacob Blake is being kept in handcuffs in hospital, his father has said - despite the 29-year-old being paralyzed from the waist down and charged with no crime. The news has sparked intense anger.

item.title: 'I was scared for my life': Harry Maguire claims Greek police attacked him
item.description: A visibly emotional Harry Maguire, 27, tonight refused to apologise for his conviction and said he was attacked by police who battered his legs
item.media:credit: speaking to BBC Sport's Dan Roan

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... Britons working from home
item.description: 'Fear you? Come, come, Mr Bond - we both know you're STILL not back in the office'

item.title: Inside Bella Thorne's OnlyFans account where she charges fans $16 (plus tips) to view VERY tame pics
item.description: The venture has already earned the American actress more than $2m (£1.52m) in revenue, singling her out as one of the most successful stars on its roster.

item.title: Mother relaxes after giving birth to 12 puppies - including little Lucky who was coaxed back to life
item.description: Dog mother Lucy (pictured) gave birth to an adorable litter of 12 pups after a long 15-hour labour in Downham Market, Norfolk.

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS reviews last night's TV: Kirstie and Phil - the princess and geezer
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Phil and Kirstie, TV's most comfortable unmarried couple, are as familiar to us as a favourite pair of old shoes.

item.title: Most Britons believe BBC are WRONG to remove lyrics from Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory
item.description: A YouGov survey shows more than half of Britons oppose the move, which comes amid claims that people are offended by the lyrics of the much-loved anthems - because they are 'racist'.

item.title: Government-funded study rules it is 'exceptionally rare' for children to die of coronavirus
item.description: Research led by the University of Liverpool found that one per cent of the 651 children admitted to hospital with Covid-19 in England died, compared to 27 per cent of adults.

item.title: London passenger's shock as medics drag suspected Covid case off plane - before it is allowed to fly
item.description: Fionn Murphy, 21, from west London, said he could be walking around Pisa spreading coronavirus because no other riders were asked to self-isolate on arrival.

item.title: Wearing funky face coverings could make them fashionable and the new normal, campaigner warns
item.description: Financier and campaigner Dame Helena Morrissey has claimed patterned face masks may make the 'unusual' times of the coronavirus pandemic 'trendy' and become the new normal.

item.title: UK policeman who fought machete attacker honoured for bravery
item.description: Pc Stuart Outten was highly commended by Metropolitan Police Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick (pictured together) at a ceremony held at New Scotland Yard.
item.media:description: Pc Stuart Outten receives his award (Metropolitan Police/PA)

item.title: Britain has the unhappiest teenagers in Europe survey shows
item.description: More than a third - 36 per cent - of 15-year-olds in the UK scored low on life satisfaction in a survey by the Children's Society. They also ranked last out of 24 European countries for 'sense of purpose'.

item.title: Android cleaner patrols school corridors and classrooms blasting out a powerful UV ray
item.description: The robots headed into Three Towers Alternative Provision Academy in Hindley, near Wigan.

item.title: The five BEST personality traits you should have to employers remember you after a job interview
item.description: Chief Executive Officer Robert van Stokrom told Australian company Seek a memorable person has confidence, curiosity, passion, great communication skills and is proactive.

item.title: Crystal handbag that once belonged to Princess Diana sells for £10,000 at auction
item.description: Diana donated the bag to a charity auction to help the homeless in February 1997, six months before her death and there was a note inside she wrote to a woman called Angela who organised the event.

item.title: Harry Potter star Jessie Cave says tennis coach raped her at 14
item.description: The 33-year-old actress, who played Ron Weasley's love interest Lavender Brown in the series, spoke bravely of her experience on a podcast with her sister Bebe.

item.title: Christchurch killer Brenton Tarrant could be transferred to Australia
item.description: The killer was on Thursday jailed for life without parole for gunning down 51 worshippers at two mosques last year. Scott Morrison said he is open to the idea of a transfer.

item.title: EU's top negotiator Michel Barnier 'rings round top Europe leaders' for support
item.description: Michel Barnier (pictured) is trying to get Boris Johnson to compromise and has asked German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron for support.

item.title: TOM UTLEY: Climb Everest in my sixties? You must be joking
item.description: TOM UTLEY: I'm full of admiration of those of my generation (I'm 66, going on 67) who retain their zest for new experiences well into the evening of their lives.

item.title: Homemade cotton masks can prevent 99.9% of coronavirus droplets from spraying into the air
item.description: A new study from the University of Edinburgh found that a homemade single-layer cotton mask reduced the number of infectious coronavirus droplets by more than 1,000 times.

item.title: Britain's beaches where motorists are most likely to be stung with parking fines
item.description: With this weekend being the first bank holiday since lockdown where travel restrictions have been relaxed, many of the 18m Britons expected to hit the road are setting their sat-navs for beaches.

item.title: I'm fed up paying for a 'woke' BBC, writes former broadcaster JAN LEEMING
item.description: JAN LEEMING When I was presenting the news on BBC1 in the 1980s I firmly believed that the Beeb was the best broadcasting outlet in the world and the channel of choice for quality.

item.title: Drink-drive crashes on Britain's roads up 3% and women at higher risk
item.description: Government road safety chiefs in the UK are looking to bring in the systems, which are installed in cars and will force drivers to pass a breath test before the vehicle's engine will start.

item.title: Bytedance asks TikTok to draw up contingency plans in case it needs to shut down in U.S.
item.description: ByteDance told TikTok engineers in a memo this week to draw up plans for shutting down the app in the U.S. in case it does not reach a deal with a buyer by the November 12 deadline, sources said.

item.title: Queen's performance at Live Aid is voted most iconic festival moment of all time
item.description: Queen's 1985 performance of We Will Rock You has been crowned the most iconic festival moment of all time.

item.title: Man was holding COMB when shot by Secret Service outside White House after 'taking shooter stance'
item.description: Myron Berryman 51, was shot outside the White House on August 10 - forcing President Trump to be abruptly led out of a press briefing by a Secret Service agent.

item.title: Donald Trump's Scottish resort charged Secret Service $1,300 for 'furniture removal' when he visited
item.description: Records show the Trump Organization charged the government at least $900,000 as Secret Service agents traveled the country to protect the president during visits to his properties.

item.title: Councils send just ONE litter fine per week as campaigners call for more 'effective' deterrent
item.description: Campaigners say the statistics, revealed through a Freedom of Information request, highlight the need for an 'effective' deterrent and have called for the £150 on-the-spot fine to be raised to £1,000.

item.title: £465,000 legal aid for PC Andrew Harper's killers with his widow Lissie 'horrified' by figure
item.description: The killers of policeman Andrew Harper have received £465,000 in legal aid. The sum was paid to solicitors and barristers defending the three teenagers who dragged the constable to his death.

item.title: JAN MOIR: Meghan speak - a guide for less than woke folk
item.description: JAN MOIR Harry and Meghan are ensconced in California and I just don't know what the hell they are talking about any more.

item.title: Harry Maguire appears to admit he COULD be stripped of Man United captaincy after Mykonos incident
item.description: Manchester United captain Maguire, 27, was clearly emotional as he described the events of that night, and added whether he remains the United skipper is 'not his decision to make'.

item.title: Could having a common cold protect you from Covid-19? Scientists given £8.4million to answer
item.description: The £8.4million will be spread across three separate studies in the UK tasked with investigating the immune response to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19.

item.title: Inside Amazon's first grocery store opening this week
item.description: The first Amazon Fresh supermarket opened in Los Angeles Thursday despite the move to online shopping as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Muslim female secret agent executed by Nazis honoured with first blue plaque for Indian-origin woman
item.description: Noor Inayat Khan is the first Indian-origin woman to be honoured with a blue plaque. The Muslim spy's tribute will be unveiled at her family home in Bloomsbury, London on Friday.

item.title: A third 'are overpaying for mobile phones' via a loyalty penalty that can cost more than £400 a year
item.description: Which? calculated that phone companies make around £182million a year from UK customers continuing to pay for a handset they already own.

item.title: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: One person's Working From Home is another's P45
item.description: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: To paraphrase Pastor Martin Niemoller, first they came for taxi drivers and I did not speak out because I was not a taxi driver.

item.title: Covid-19 has brought out Britain's 'Blitz spirit', scientists say
item.description: King's College London researchers analysed documents from between 1938 to 1945, comparing the public's wartime response to our behaviour during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Man appears in court over threatening email to Conservative MP
item.description: Ian Howgate, 56, of Leys Garden, Newbury, Berkshire, allegedly sent an email to the Newbury Conservative MP Laura Farris which spoke of the killing of British politician Andrew Pennington.

item.title: Organs from elderly donors can be 'rejuvenated', says study
item.description: Researchers tested old mice with senylotic drugs, which target and eliminate old cells, and was shown to reduce mitochondrial DNA levels, which causes inflammation and is linked to organ rejection.

item.title: Bristol police Taser a knife-wielding one-armed roller skater moments after he stabbed three victims
item.description: Benjamin Bridgeman, 38, is on trial accused of attempted murder following the shocking attacks in Knowle, Bristol, earlier this year.

item.title: Hospital at centre of a maternity scandal is the first to face action over high coronavirus rates
item.description: The Care Quality Commission has issued a legal order against East Kent Hospitals NHS Trust, making it the first to face action over high coronavirus rates.

item.title: UK's biggest bookie makes £1.3bn as gamblers blow millions in lockdown
item.description: Flutter - which runs the Paddy Power, Betfair and SkyBet websites - said the staggering figure was a fifth higher than in the same period last year.

item.title: Aston Martin reveals a scaled-down electric DB5 £54,000
item.description: It is powered by a battery driven 6.7bhp 5kW electric motor driving the rear wheels up to a top speed on the standard DB5 Junior of 30mph. A racier version has more power and a top speed of 50mph.

item.title: Leeds Greggs distribution centre shutdown as workers test positive for the coronavirus
item.description: Around 20 staff members at the distribution centre (pictured) in Bramley, near Leeds, West Yorkshire, had caught the killer virus.

item.title: Hurricane Laura makes landfall in Louisiana with 150mph winds
item.description: Hurricane Laura has killed five people, including a 14-year-old girl, after trees fell on their homes when the Category 4 storm system smashed into Texas and Louisiana with 150mph winds.

item.title: 'Wake up or towns will die': Tory MPs sound alarm to Boris Johnson over future of our High Streets
item.description: Pret a Manger became the latest victim of the working-from-home culture yesterday, after seeing a decade of growth wiped out in months as a result of the UK lockdown.

item.title: Olive Thomas was one of Hollywood's first starlets - but ended up guzzling poison 100 years ago
item.description: Olive Thomas's death is clouded in mystery. All we know for certain is that the 25-year-old actress and international beauty - one of the original Jazz Age flappers - died in unimaginable agony.

item.title: Harry Maguire fans sent threats to Greek prosecution lawyer
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Lawyer Ioannis Paradissis said he found the messages 'disgusting' and said the anger should be turned on the fallen Manchester United star and not him.

item.title: Hart to Hart's Stefanie Powers, 77, buys groceries in LA
item.description: Hart to Hart actress Stefanie Powers was spotted in a rare public appearance during a grocery run in Los Angeles on Monday, exclusive DailyMail.com photos show.

item.title: For shepherd JAMES REBANKS, farming isn't just a way of life, it's in his blood
item.description: JAMES REBANKS; The black-headed gulls follow in our wake as if we are a little fishing boat out at sea, their winged silhouettes and screaming beaks filling the sky above my grandfather's tractor.

item.title: Ecuadorian couple are world's oldest married pair - 80 years after families disapproved of wedding
item.description: Guinness World Records has acknowledged Waldramina Quintero, 104, and Julio César Mora, 110, as the oldest married couple. The couple married in 1941 and lives in Ecuador.

item.title: R Kelly 'attacked by inmate' as he awaits trial in Chicago prison
item.description: The singer, 53, main, remains jailed in the city's Metropolitan Correctional Center, inset, after pleading not guilty to state and federal sex crime charges in Illinois, Minnesota and New York.

item.title: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Heartache for Lord Heseltine's daughter Annabel as scammers ruin holiday
item.description: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Lord Heseltine has a fortune of nearly £300million, but that doesn't mean his elder daughter, Annabel, is invulnerable to holiday horror.

item.title: Man driving Tesla on autopilot crashed car while watching film
item.description: Devainder Goli of Raleigh, North Carolina, was driving his Tesla on autopilot and watching a movie on his cell phone when his vehicle rammed into a police car on Wednesday morning

item.title: Disturbing new footage shows gunman, 17, 'shooting dead his first victim' in Kenosha
item.description: Kyle Rittenhouse, 17, was arrested on Wednesday at his home in Antioch, Illinois, 20 miles from Kenosha. He is accused of killing two people, inset, at protests over Jacob Blake's shooting Tuesday.

item.title: Gareth Southgate's plans for England's double-header in disarray after squad members test positive
item.description: Sportsmail believes at least four players in Southgate's squad have tested positive in recent days and must now wait to see if they have to withdraw from the party to play Iceland and Denmark.

item.title: Michael Cohen pens scathing attack on President Trump
item.description: Michael Cohen worked as Donald Trump's personal attorney and his 'fixer' for more than a decade, once saying he would 'take a bullet' for his boss,

item.title: TikTok star breaks down in tears while slamming trolls who attack her lavish lifestyle
item.description: Nabela Noor, who is South Asian and Muslim, defended her success as the daughter of immigrants and noted that it has been a difficult year for her in the clip.

item.title: The rusting maritime heap off the coast of Essex which makes up nation known as Sealand
item.description: Sealand, by Dylan Taylor-Lehman, tells the story of the rusting WW2 fort off the coast of Harwich, Essex, which Roy Jenkins found in 1967, and declared independent from the UK.

item.title: Study says dating profiles showing Apple products more popular
item.description: Researchers have found showing Apple products in your dating photos can boost the odds of a match by as much as 76 percent. Most other brands, including Google, lowered the chances of a match.

item.title: Paratrooper hero of the Falklands War is selling his military medals for £120,000
item.description: Retired Falklands hero Captain John Pettinger, of the Parachute Regiment, is selling his Distinguished Conduct Medal along with five other bravery medals for an expected £120,000 at auction.

item.title: What makes an Olympic champion
item.description: Annie Vernon has won two world championships and an Olympic silver as a rower. She explains what makes elite athletes elite, revealing they're not superhuman but, deep down, they're just like us.

item.title: Abandoned as a baby, Charlie Gilmour struggled until a magpie helped him fly free of his demons
item.description: Charlie Gilmour's memoir, Fatherhood, is so original and ingeniously wrought, it stands on its own as a book to which others will surely be compared.

item.title: Meghan Markle accused of hypocrisy over 'linked not ranked' quote
item.description: Meghan, 39, called attention to the quote during a Q&A with activist Gloria, 86, revealing that she wears bracelets with the mantra written on them.

item.title: Hide behind the zebra-print sofa... TV's Changing Rooms is back!
item.description: If Channel 4 really is hoping to bring back Changing Rooms for the 2020s, it would be fantastic. I adored the eight years I spent on the programme.

item.title: Police officer accused of asking woman for threesome is sacked
item.description: PC Darren Booth was accused of propositioning the woman, who was suffering from alcoholism, after he was called to deal with reports of anti-social behaviour in Castleford, West Yorks.

item.title: World's most expensive sheep sells at £365k at Scottish auction
item.description: The lamb, named Double Diamond, was sold to farmers at the Scottish National Texel sale in Lanark on Thursday.

item.title: YouTuber finds £1m fleet of classic cars in abandoned garage
item.description: A prototype Bristol Bullet, a Bentley Continental Flying Spur and a 1957 vintage Beardmore taxi were among the extraordinary treasure trove of seemingly abandoned cars.

item.title: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry 'morphing into John and Yoko'
item.description: The Sussexes, who quit the Firm in March and moved to the US, have embraced a bohemian style and are seeking to become a 'power couple for global harmony', Judi James told Fabulous.

item.title: Damian Hurley, 18, seen out as details of father's will emerge
item.description: The budding model, 18, who is the son of actress Elizabeth Hurley, opted for a low-key look of black joggers and a jumper as he was joined by a pal.

item.title: Father abducts his sons from London foster home at knifepoint
item.description: Met Police are searching for Imran Safi after he abducted his three biological children from their foster home at knifepoint in Coulsdon, south London.

item.title: Online shopping tycoon is set for huge windfall when his business floats on stock market
item.description: Matthew Moulding started the company in 2004 and will be awarded shares worth £700million if the company's valuation reaches £7.25 billion.

item.title: Majority of Windrush scandal compensation claimants are still without payment
item.description: The scheme was set up after thousands of people from Caribbean countries and their families were wrongly classified as illegal immigrants by the Home Office in 2018.

item.title: New Giraffe Hall where you can dine with the long-necked animals will open in Kent
item.description: Port Lympne Hotel and Reserve in Kent hopes to open the highly-anticipated Giraffe Hall next summer after plans to build it were given the go-ahead.

item.title: Sir Ed Davey elected new leader of the Liberal Democrats
item.description: Sir Ed, who served as a Cabinet minister in the Coalition Government, said the party needed to 'wake up and smell the coffee' after suffering three crushing general elections in a row.

item.title: Eat Out to Help Out: Restaurants extend scheme voluntarily
item.description: The UK restaurants will continue the 50 per cent discount into September, which the Government has financed through August.

item.title: Extinction Rebellion plans bank holiday weekend of protests
item.description: A four-day 'regional rebellion' from tomorrow until Bank Holiday Monday will see protests across the UK, including in London, Manchester, Bristol, Cardiff and Leeds.

item.title: Jameela Jamil puts on a loved-up display with beau James Blake on a beach in California
item.description: The Good Place star, 34, and the singer-songwriter, 31, looked happier than ever as they took a romantic stroll on a beach in Montecito, California on Wednesday.

item.title: The baby names that are falling out of fashion
item.description: For girls, Kirsty, appears to have fallen out of fashion, with only four babies given the name last year and a drop in use of a whopping 99 per cent since 2000 - while Mitchell was least popular for boys.

item.title: Finnish conductor of the Proms 'did NOT axe Rule Britannia'
item.description: Dalia Stasevska, 35, has now spoken out in a statement, insisting she had no part in the BBC's decision to not have Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory sung at the Proms.

item.title: 1 in 4 in Medieval Europe may have had parasitic roundworms
item.description: According to the researchers from the University of Oxford, the findings of the study could help fight worm infections in countries where such remain endemic today.

item.title: Two teenage boys tortured, raped and buried alive in Sweden
item.description: The boys were set upon allegedly by a 21-year-old and an 18-year-old at around 11pm on Saturday evening in Solna, Sweden.

item.title: 38 fined for not wearing masks on public transport in lockdown
item.description: Latest data from the National Police Chiefs's Council shows a total of 18,683 fines were issued in England and Wales between March 27 and August 17, but some were for more than one reason.

item.title: Uninsured drink-driver who killed woman gets nine years' jail
item.description: Godwin Ohue, 40, has been jailed for nine years after crashing into another car and killing Darcy Bruce-Lawrence, 20, on June 28, 2019, in Dartford, Kent. He was four times over the drink-driving limit.

item.title: Comets didn't bring Earth's water as it 'was here from the start', study finds
item.description: A new study by the Centre de Recherches Petrographiques et Geochimiques, France, examined a meteorite called an enstatite chondrite for signs of hydrogen.

item.title: Drug that 'repairs damage to the brain and spinal cord' has been created by British scientists
item.description: Scientists led by Cambridge University created a synthetic version of a protein known as Cerebellin-1, called CPTX, that links brain messaging neurons together.

item.title: Books behind Boris Johnson WERE arranged to convey message
item.description: The former librarian at Castle Rock School in Coalville, Leicestershire, said the books were a message, but they were aimed at her former bosses and not Boris Johnson.

item.title: Amazon takes aim at Fitbit and Apple with new Halo health tracker
item.description: Amazon unveiled a health and fitness tracker called Halo. The wristband monitors emotion, sleep, body and activity, and pits the firm against the likes of Fitbit and Apple - to major players in the market.

item.title: 3D scans show baby sauropods had a horn and binocular vision
item.description: The extraordinary fossil specimen from Patagonia represents the most complete and articulate skull found to date of any titanosaur - which were the world's largest-ever land animals.

item.title: Test and Trace gets worse... AGAIN: Record-low 72.6% of infected patients were reached
item.description: It's the fifth week in a row the figure has fallen, after the highest level of 82.8 per cent of cases in England were reached in the week ending July 22.

item.title: Switzerland, Jamaica and the Czech Republic added to the UK quarantine list
item.description: Travellers arriving in the UK after 4am on Saturday from those nations will have to self-isolate for 14 days, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps announced this evening.

item.title: Drug for CATS may help fight coronavirus in humans, study finds
item.description: A team of scientists at the University of Alberta in Canada found in lab tests that the medicine GC376 could destroy the virus that causes Covid-19, even though it was made for a different coronavirus.

item.title: Giant 'Avozilla' avocados weighing almost 4lbs are hitting supermarket shelves tomorrow
item.description: A bumper crop of the South African-grown Avozillas are on offer this year thanks to a great harvest and perfect growing conditions in the hot climate abroad and will go on sale at 300 tstoes.

item.title: Fraudster on run from eight year jail term over £2.4m fraud is finally behind bars
item.description: Sami Raja, 33, from Essex, was formally handed an eight year sentence at Southwark Crown Court after being convicted of six counts of conspiracy to defraud and money laundering.

item.title: First complete dinosaur skeleton found 160 years ago finally studied
item.description: Researchers from the University of Cambridge spent the past three years preparing a detailed description and biological analysis of the skeleton of the Scelidosaurus.

item.title: UK coronavirus deaths announced for Thursday
item.description: NHS England confirmed the deaths of seven more of its patients between May 15 and August 26, while one more victim was announced by Public Health Wales.

item.title: Britain's oldest identical twins celebrate turning 100 after moving in together
item.description: Dorothy Sivyer and Kathleen Whitehead, who moved in together at the start of lockdown to keep each other company, say their secret is a balance of wine, chocolate, exercise and healthy food.

item.title: Amol Rajan tells Lord Hall about fears the BBC is becoming 'broadcasting wing of the BLM movement'
item.description: Amol Rajan told Lord Hall colleagues raised 'deep concern' that UK broadcasting giant has 'in effect become the broadcasting wing of the Black Lives Matter movement'.

item.title: Seaside towns lead the post-lockdown march back to normality
item.description: Blackpool, Bournemouth and Southend among the areas becoming busy with shoppers, workers and tourists again - alongside Birkenhead, Basildon, Chatham and Doncaster.

item.title: Vladimir Putin has formed 'special force' and says he is ready to intervene in Belarus
item.description: Vladimir Putin has confirmed that he has created a reserve police force that he is ready to deploy into Belarus if protests against President Alexander Lukashenko 'get out of control'.

item.title: Man pays £6,000 to have his EARS removed so his head looks like a skull - and keeps them in a jar
item.description: Sandro, known as 'Mr Skull Face' on social media, insisted his transformed appearance made him feel more confident even though others called him 'disturbed' and 'sick'.

item.title: Losing weight is easier if your spouse joins in: Success rate is almost THREE times higher
item.description: Heart attack patients in the Netherlands keen to drop the pounds lost more weight when their partner joined in compared to patients whose partner did not.

item.title: German tyre firm Continental used concentration camp prisoners as slave labour
item.description: German tyre-maker Continental used prisoners from the Sachsenhausen concentration camp (pictured) as slave labour during World War Two by forcing them to test shoe soles, the firm admitted.

item.title: Royal drama college accused of covering up 'sex attacks' on two actresses by fellow student
item.description: The Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama - whose President is Prince Charles - has been accused by 16 women over their botched handling of the sex attacks.

item.title: Look who's talking already! Incredible moment 10-week-old baby tells her mother: 'I love you'
item.description: Chloe Davis, 18, from St Albans, shared a video to TikTok of her newborn Scarlett-Rose lying in her crib in a sweet red outfit and bow, saying 'I love you' at just 10-weeks-old.

item.title: Europe's second wave takes hold as cases rise in France, Italy and Spain
item.description: Cases of coronavirus are on the rise across Europe, with France logging 5,426 cases on Wednesday - its third-highest daily total ever, as Prime Minister Jean Castex said the R figure is now at 1.4.

item.title: Successful asylum claims DOUBLE in seven years to more than 20,000 a year
item.description: More people are now granted asylum in Britain that are refused it, according to Home Office statistics. Some 9,605 cases were approved in 2013, compared to 20,692 last year.

item.title: Matt Hancock misses the 'WFH' memo! Health Secretary has 'no idea' where staff are working
item.description: The Health Secretary's comments came amid a massive push by Boris Johnson's Government and business leaders to breathe life into the UK's high streets by refilling the nation's workplaces.

item.title: Save the Last Night of the Proms
item.description: More than 100,000 people have signed the MailOnline petition urging the BBC to reverse its censorship of the two iconic songs.

item.title: Two of PC Andrew Harper's killers 'are planning to write a book about their crime
item.description: Sources said both Albert Bowers and Jessie Cole, 18-year-olds from a travelling community in Reading, are 'strutting around like celebrities' in Belmarsh Prison in South London.

item.title: PC Andrew Harper's killers could have manslaughter jail terms INCREASED
item.description: The Attorney General today referred the sentences of PC Andrew Harper's killers Albert Bowers, Jessie Cole and Henry Long to the Court of Appeal.
